Message.Title: Why AMZN profit margin went up a little last quarter
Message.Msg: It is because their volume was less than expected. That is the problem in the model. Because they will be selling less due to the economy, taxes, & competition the growth will stop, the profit margin might go up a little, but gross and net profits will continue to fall. If they sell things even cheaper, then they will make even less money or lose a lot of money. It is a lose, lose situation. In addition they are also suspect to internet security problems, internet traffic issues, & stoppage.

Topic.Title: Futures up HUGE = short gunna get pwned tomorrow

Message.Msg: "I suspect bandwagon bond shorts are going to get squeezed and soon." I agree with that. Hasn't happened yet. The "full court media press" is on every where from WS to the media CNBC/Bloomberg platforms that bond money to stocks. They both have gone up the last 4 years on leveraging. There's the Black Swan focus in my view: this Central Banks leverage buildup: now the Fed owns the equivalent of 29 % of outstanding 10 yr bond duration. They are becoming the bond market here. And at the whim of adverse moves. It's a game of high stakes poker to keep doing this here as bubbles are being created with this money. It won't end well in my view. "Every day these scams continue to rise, more damage is done to trust. " Scams show up when easy money is high: look at the tech bubbles , housing bubbles of yesteryear where stocks in tech reached billions with no sales in the tech one and CDO deritvative sausage pushed in the last one so the last house could be sold to someone who couldn't afford it. It's easy to create the AMZN story under conditions of $85 billion of Fed open ended buying here. The tabs on them now lately as rates are backing up.

Message.Title: Amazon finally moving in the right direction.
Message.Msg: This stock has been going in the wrong direction for a long time. When it hit 200, people should have considered what they were paying for. Amazon is just a bit different than the online version of Walmart. In that case it will take 5 years of perfection just to equal Walmart. Suggests to me that maybe the stock should be around 100. Sure they are growing, but they also have competition. Just like Walmart. I know people that prefer other online outlets over amazon. Overstock or Macy's. And their tablets are making only a little bit of money. So all profits come from cloud. And there is a huge amount of competition in that business. Microsoft , Google, and then dedicated providers.

Message.Title: Amazon Only Looks Expensive
Message.Msg: It's really not expensive. Why? Profits are low because Amazon has invested over $10 billion dollars in 2012 alone on fulfillment centers and huge data centers. Did they have to invest that much money in 1 year? No they didn't. That money could have gone to the other side of the ledger, and AMZN management could have easily just posted a big EPS instead of reinvesting the capital. When you consider the company has a $120 market cap, but invested $10 billion back into the business instead of showing a large EPS, AMZN is not expensive. And you know people were saying the exact same thing when AMZN was trading at $45.......looked just as expensive then as it does today. A couple other interesting AMZN points. There are about 365 million shares of float, and Jeff Bezos own about 25% of the float personally. Finally, I don't see any direct competitor to AMZN, and IMO AMZN already has the most sophisticated and most efficient distribution system in the world.

Message.Title: Looks like the Option Boys want 265.so it is written. so it will be done.
Message.Msg: The selling is 3 times the buying but that 265 is like a magnet. Probably where they make the most money on the earnings move up, then down. Everybody needs to learn: Hedgies: They make their salary and nice living trading stocks, bonds and alternatives. Buy ferraris, 20K sq feet homes, and islands in the pacfic on options.. Take are little stock here. The premiums on both side of 270 right before earnings were huge. We had this 15pt move up in the aftermarket and then a slow sell off from that high the next day but still up 10 bucks-and the near term calls-they dropped by 50%.....as did the puts. My favotie scam here....that mysterious close right before the earnings. In 10 seconds we went from 268 to a close of 260-closing the gap on the chart. Nobody can explain it EXCEPT that because that "gap' no longer exists the algorythms will not use that price in their calculations. what a scam. These boys may have made as much as 20 million on near term options in the last 2 days...............

Topic.Title: Amazon Only Looks Expensive

Message.Msg: agree, it is just another retailer after it started collecting sales tax. It has no more pricing advantage. Costco and Walmart can provide services in the physical stores, such as tire center and eye exam/glasses, or even food. Amazon cannot do anything like this. When consumers buy big ticket items(such as high end digital cameras, people buy somewhere else to save few hundred tax). The only two options I see for Amazon are * Keep the price high and its revenue will be flat or even shrinking * Keep the price low to have about 15% growth in revenue and have very poor margin.

Topic.Title: Morgan Stanley Issues $16MM of Securities that Bet on Amazon Move

Message.Msg: AMZN gets cash by selling OTC out of the money puts to MS. The additional cash is accounted for as an increase in paid in capital in excess of par so most security analysts and the public don't even see how it got there. AMZN then uses the cash to buy back their stock. The derivative security issued by MS enables them to transfer away the risk of purchasing the otc puts from AMZN to purchasers of the security. The potential profits are retained by MS. Security purchasers pay MS a premium to risk taking a loss. Nice work if you can get it.

Topic.Title: please respond to the fellow that called the 265 close! its amazing how you guys know this stuff

Message.Msg: You can gauge the so-called Max Pain theory by finding the strike price of the nearest expiry month that has the most added open interests on both the calls and puts contracts. Currently, Feb 13 (with 14 days left): (PUTS open interest + CALLS open interest = total) 260 strike = 3354 + 1587 = 4941 265 strike = 3279 + 1894 = 5173 270 strike = 5808 + 4915 = 10723 275 strike = 1816 + 4371 = 6187 280 strike = 1607 + 4250 = 5857 Open interests are contracts that are sold (or bought depending on your strategy); however, most savvy option traders would want to sell near month contracts due to rapid time decay. Only the amateur option traders will go buy near month contracts and use them as a lottery ticket to hedge their position. The fact of option contract is that both call/put buyers will lose everything on their contracts if the closing price lands smack on the strike price. So that is painful to the option buyer. As the Max Pain theory goes, most of these contracts are sold by big boys who have deep pockets. Since they are sellers, their main interest is to see your option contracts go to zero. Stock prices, therefore, will tend to be pinned at a strike price that has the most combined call/put open interests because that is where these big boys sold their contracts, and where they can inflict most pain on these amateur option traders. AMZN at the moment would likely to be pinned at $270 if these Feb 13 options were to expire today. This number will change and the most accurate one is obviously the one that closes on the expiry day. Hope this helps. Good luck!

Message.Title: AMZN retail business got dead lock
Message.Msg: Continue Revenue Growth(say above 20%): It has to keep price low, lower than other stores which do not collect sales tax. So, the margin will be lower than before. Flat or Shrinking revenue: to have health and reasonable margin(close to Costco or Walmart). There is just no way to have high margin and high growth in the future because * Its base is already too big to have growth. * Consumers only have loyalty to the price. Won't like to pay higher price for the same products What is the solution for Amazon ? I think its CEO probably couldn't figure out and sold almost $200 million worth shares at the end of last year.
